Headline.Para: Cut the cutlery if you don't need it, says foodpanda

Snippet.Para: Food delivery service says more customers opting out of disposable cutlery
OPTING not to have disposable cutlery with food delivery orders is often a quick way to go green.

ReplyItem.Byline: Navin Sregantan , Cut the cutlery if you don't need it, says foodpanda

Headline.Para: Cut the cutlery if you don't need it, says foodpanda

LeadPara.Para: Food delivery service says more customers opting out of disposable cutlery

TailParas.Para: OPTING not to have disposable cutlery with food delivery orders is often a quick way to go green.
Since the start of the year, customers using foodpanda have to able to do so. The idea for this drive was conceived in December 2017; shortly after foodpanda completed its rebranding exercise.

In an interview with The Business Times, foodpanda's head of marketing and sustainability lead Laura Kantor says: "With so many orders going to an office or a home, where cutlery is readily available, we saw this as an important way to significantly reduce our plastic use. It's a small step that can make a world of difference."

"Our current corporate social responsibility strategy looks at three environmental areas we believe we can make the most impact. This focuses on environmentally friendly packaging, less waste and sustainable food."
Since making disposable cutlery an option for its customers, take up rates have grown steadily.
By the end of the first week, 10 per cent of all orders received by foodpanda were placed with an opt out for cutlery. It has since grown to 23 per cent of all orders.

The results are encouraging and also reflective of shifts in attitudes towards sustainability. "We certainly expect an increase in number of customers choosing to opt out as they become increasingly aware of the devastating impact of plastic waste," says Ms Kantor.
foodpanda also supports the World Wildlife Foundation's (WWF's) "Say No To Shark Fin" pledge.

WWF worked with a range of food and beverage outlet operators including foodpanda partners like Crystal Jade. Together, they have pledged to remove shark fin dishes from their menus by the end of 2018.

"As Singapore is the second largest importer of shark fins globally, we feel that foodpanda Singapore has a huge part to play in protecting an important species from going extinct and have decided to remove all shark products from our menu by March 5," she says.
For about 3 per cent of foodpanda's restaurant partners in Singapore who still serve shark fin, these dishes are not available for delivery.

Douglas DeBoer, chief executive officer of Crystal Jade Culinary Holdings feels such efforts will catch on as more restaurants come on board to protect "oceans and seafood supplies, as socially responsible businesses".

Ultimately, foodpanda wants to phase out the use of plastic packaging. On a global level, it is working with Forum for the Future - a British non-government organisation - to look at a strategy to phase out plastic packaging and introduce environmentally friendly alternatives.
Ms Kantor says: "This is still in the planning phases, and we're hoping to roll this out within the first half of 2018."

Article.Byline: Navin Sregantan , Cut the cutlery if you don't need it, says foodpanda
Article.Art: It's a long road, but foodpanda aims to phase out the use of plastic packaging and introduce environmentally friendly alternatives.
